newsitem.title: USA: CME to expand large order execution pilot program.
newsitem.headline: CME to expand large order execution pilot program.

text.p: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange will expand and alter its large order execution (LOX) system program for currency futures starting August 26.

In a floor notice on Wednesday, the CME said the changes, which CME's board passed August 7 and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission approved August 19, would expand the pilot program to all nine currency futures pits.
Currently, only German mark futures are traded on the personal-computer-based system that is designed to lure customers back into futures from the over-the-counter market.

CME extended the life of the LOX pilot program to January 15, 1997, from its original ending date of September 10, 1996, and it set at 200 the minimum parcel of contracts required to execute a LOX trade.
Currently, LOX trades in mark futures must consist of at least 400 contracts.
The exchange also raised to 90 seconds from 60 seconds the amount of time LOX requests-for-quotes (RFQs) are allowed.
The board gave its LOX oversight committee discretion to set the amount of time for RFQs anywhere between one and three minutes, the notice said.
